title: Daniel Kadoke
text: I am Daniel Kadoke, a biostatistician with a strong passion for data-driven research and evidence-based decision making. I work extensively with R and Stata to analyze, model, and interpret complex health and biological data. I am highly hardworking, detail-oriented, and committed to delivering accurate, reliable, and impactful results. I enjoy turning data into clear insights that support research, policy, and real-world solutions.

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

The image you see Above highlights essential elements, especially in the world of data analytics. A statistician begins the day early before the noise and distractions set in. The pen is always the first to move, sketching questions in the notebook: 1.Why did the model fail? 2.What does the data really say?
This is where Probability Theory and Statistical Inference take shape on paper, transforming curiosity into clear, testable hypotheses.
With a cup of coffee beside the notebook, coding begins. Coffee sharpens focus, and writing ideas down helps organize thought, enabling the statistician to reason carefully while working through R, Python, and statistical models. In this quiet moment, patterns begin to emerge and numbers start to speak.
A powerful, reliable computer makes the work smoother and more enjoyable. Many analytical tasks, such as fitting complex regression models, generating visualizations, and running simulations require strong computing power. A slow system can interrupt thinking and reduce productivity. This is the core of Data Analysis, Machine Learning, and Applied Statistics, where efficiency matters.
The phone is present not as a distraction, but as a gateway to opportunity. A data analyst stays alert to new trends, research updates, and career possibilities. Then it chimes with a message from a teammate: ‚ÄúCan you explain the result?‚Äù A quick response and a shared chart follow. This is where Data Visualization, Communication for Data Science, and Reproducible Research become essential because insights only matter when they are understood and trusted.
Together, these simple objects tell a powerful story: data analysis is not just about numbers it is about thinking critically, learning continuously, communicating clearly, and staying curious.

title: Statistics
text: If you want, I can write you a ready-to-go template for a Quarto blog post with all your ‚Äústatistician motivation + tools + coffee + computer + phone‚Äù story included. That way you can just copy, paste, and publish immediately.

title: The Five Steps to Trustworthy Analysis
text:
Data analysis principle!

Before opening R, Python, or any software, take time to understand the question, the context, and the data generating process. Good analysis does not start with code it starts with clear thinking. Ask yourself: What decision will this analysis inform? What does success look like?
Writing ideas in a notebook helps structure your thoughts. Sketch assumptions, note possible biases, and outline the steps you plan to take. This habit strengthens reasoning and prevents blind trial-and-error modeling.
-Once coding begins, work step by step:
-Explore the data before modeling
-Visualize patterns before fitting equations
-Validate assumptions before interpreting results

title: Daniel Kadoke Nyakwela
Self-reported life satisfaction, 2011 to 2023
text:
Happiness across the world over time
The World Happiness Report is a well-known source of cross-country data on self-reported life satisfaction, collected by the Gallup World Poll. The visualizations below present the ‚Äòhappiness scores‚Äô for each country.
The main life evaluation question asked in the poll is the Cantril Life Ladder question:

‚ÄúPlease imagine a ladder, with steps numbered from 0 at the bottom to 10 at the top. The top of the ladder represents the best possible life for you and the bottom of the ladder represents the worst possible life for you. On which step of the ladder would you say you personally feel you stand at this time?‚Äù


üî¢ Tableüåé Mapüìà Simple Chartüìà Advanced Chartüìà Top 10 and bottom 10 countries


Average self-reported life satisfaction ‚Äì Cantril Ladder score (0=worst; 10=best)


# A tibble: 171 √ó 5
   Country     `2011` `2023` Absolute_change Relative_change
   <chr>        <dbl>  <dbl>           <dbl> <chr>          
 1 Afghanistan   4.26   1.72           -2.54 -59.6%         
 2 Africa        4.45   4.38           -0.07 -1.6%          
 3 Albania       5.13   5.30            0.17 3.3%           
 4 Algeria       5.37   5.36            0    0.0%           
 5 Angola        4.18  NA              NA    <NA>           
 6 Argentina     6.24   6.19           -0.05 -0.8%          
 7 Armenia       4.47   5.45            0.98 21.9%          
 8 Asia          4.98   5.08            0.1  2.0%           
 9 Australia     7.34   7.06           -0.29 -3.9%          
10 Austria       7.23   6.90           -0.32 -4.4%          
# ‚Ñπ 161 more rows




The map plots the average answer that survey respondents provided to this question in different countries. As with the steps of the ladder, values in the map range from 0 to 10.
















One problem with the simple chart on the previous tab is that the countries are fixed. It would be better if the user could select the countries they want to see. This is not possible with plotly alone, but with the crosstalk package and some custom JavaScript, we can achieve this, as demonstrated below.
This is simply a demonstration for you, you do not need to work on this for your assignment. You may want to come back to this when you need such functionality in your own projects.
For more information on how we achieved this, see this Stack Overflow question.






Select a country to examine
